Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: I got to learn a lot more more tropical forests. I also got the chance to research a learn a lot more about a topic I really liked for my project.

up to date understanding of state of science and research directions in tropical forest ecology (and some related fields), refreshed ability to efficiently read scientific papers, complicated preconceived notions about some basic ecological principles in a way that will better inform conservation efforts I'm involved in during my career
I learned some forest ecology principles that I hadn't been previously exposed to.
I learned a lot about tropical ecology and exactly how important of a topic it is to climate change and global warming. I also learned how to read scientific reports in ecology.
From basic to complex concepts behind tropical forest diversity, functions, findings and threats.
a deep dive into the most current scholarship on tropical ecology, a balanced overview of literature studies and conservation experience and methodology
I guess reading papers, but I didn't feel challenged from this course.
natural science perspective on tropical forests

Overview of issues and concepts about the tropics.  I think the papers assigned gave good experience assessing scientific reading and discussing it with others. The final project was my first introduction to that kind of bibliography so that was interesting.
I learned a lot about tropical forests and some more esoteric topics in ecology in general.
The basics of tropical forest ecology. Also, some interesting ecological theories that I had never heard of before and that were very interesting (Neutral Theory, Janzen-Connell Hypothesis).
Overview of tropical forest dynamics and recent research on tropical ecology

Because I am coming to the MF without a strong background in Ecology, this course was really helpful in catching me up on basic Ecology concepts that apply to all types of forests and ecosystems, not just tropical forests. I'm glad I took this course my first semester at F&ES because I think it serves as a jumping-off point for more specific areas of study. I appreciated that Liza always made sure to present the most up-to-date research on the topics at hand and I feel like I came away with a good general understanding of the world of tropical forest research.
This was a good overview to tropical forests that covered the major relevant ecological concepts and conservation concerns.
Ecology of tropical forests; the factors that shape them and problems these ecosystems face.
Second half of the semester was more journal article based than I thought
The knowledge, skills, and insights gained from this class aligned pretty well with my expectations.
the knowledge, skills, and insights gained aligned well with my expectations
I wish we had gone deeper into the specific ecology of tropical forests.
I was not sure what to expect with this class but I was not disappointed.
This class exceeded my expectations in terms of all the topics and details it went into. Truly a wonderful class!
quite well
Pretty well, but a lot of the material was a review
very well
Well.  Overall liked the class better than I expected to (not that I expected not to like it).
They aligned with my expectations for what the course would be like.
The knowledge gained in this class aligned with my expectations.
Very well - a lot of it wasnt new to me because I have a background in ecology, but the inclusion of new research kept it fresh and interesting.

I was concerned that my lack of background in Ecology would hinder my success in this course, but Liza is a good teacher and she can make advanced ecological concepts accessible even to students new to the field.

It was a little more elementary in the ecological side than I was expecting. I would have liked more scientific course work that forced us to apply the concepts we were learning. The papers we read were fascinating and did offer a deeper ecological dive. I would have liked assignments or quizzes more focused on integrating all of that information throughout the semester. It felt like we covered it and then moved on.
Exceeded expectations; interesting topics and guest lectures outside the general scope of what I expected.

I felt the textbook was pretty easy to comprehend, and I enjoyed the guest lectures, who presented on a pretty varied list of topics. I also appreciated that we could pick whatever topic we wanted for our final project, as long as it related to tropic forests.
I think it would have been better if the professor had posted the slides at least a few days before the lecture, so that students could print out the slides if they wanted to in order to take notes on them.
I would like to have learned more about ecological impacts of forest product extraction and ways in which impacts can be mitigated
I think the work load could be a bit heavier. It would be good to have other assignments throughout the semester other than reading articles and answering basic questions about them.
Professor Comita is a great teacher and is extremely knowledgeable. I cannot think of any weakness of the course.
I don't find weaknesses to this class; it is excellent!

The strongest part of the course was access to Liza and the host of speakers that she brought in to the class to speak on current research and thinking about tropical ecology issues. great lectures and well structured student engagement. good balance of reading and testing/group work

It could be more rigorous or go more in depth with complex topics.  There was too much review of ecology.

I don't understand why a take home final was necessary.  We had enough grades throughout the semester and a final project.
Professor Comita is a great lecturer. She makes the content interesting through personal engagement with the topic and bringing in contemporary research.

The lectures were really informative and I really love the inclusion of recent research to back up what the topic of the day was.  It was cool to see so many different ways that experiments and analysis are done.  The discussions were nice but the ones where we had more structured points to focus on were more productive.

Strengths: relevant recent scientific papers and reasonable workload most of the time. Interesting topics. Weakness: workload at the end was more than called for (presentation + project + exam). Occassionally too simplistic / too slow of a pace in lectures for concepts covered in general ecology. Textbook was almost useless. Would have loved to discuss articles more in terms of critiquing their methods and results instead of assuming they are correct all the time.

I thought this course was well-structured. I liked the project at the end of the course as it gave me the flexibility to dive into the topic of my interest. The final exam seemed like an extra, unnecessary add-on.
It was a little slow for me at times but because the professor was balancing a lot of different levels, I dont think theres much that can be done there

The strengths of the course were that it provided a broad overview of ecological concepts that are applicable to tropical forests and often temperate forests as well. It was a well-structured course with regular reading questions that ensure everyone has a knowledge of the readings and can participate in discussions. Liza often brings in speakers with experience in particular fields which I found informative and enjoyable. 

The weaknesses of this course may be that the level of difficulty of the material is a bit low for students with a background in ecology.

The breadth of this course is amazing, the depth in some sections was lacking and in others it went beyond my expectations. Having Liza as an instructor is definitely a huge strength for her area of focus and all of her background knowledge. It was a please to have her as an instructor but I feel like I spent the semester enjoying this course rather than taking my own competency to a higher level. I am more aware of many topics but would have like more specialization. The final projects offered that opportunity, I would have liked to have done that with multiple topics throughout the semester but am not sure what I would have cut out to make time for that.
Course was large, could have been improved with a smaller class and more discussion.
It's a pretty standard class in terms of lecture slides and readings. The readings can vary in workload per week, so be sure to keep that in mind with regards to your readings for other classes.

Take this course - the professor's approach is no-nonsense, wants her students to learn and expects quality discussion but assigns very reasonable work and is willing to accommodate your interests. Guest lectures are fun and unlike other classes where end-of-term presentations by students seem like a waste of time, it is genuinely enjoyable to learn about other peoples' interests and reasons for taking this class because of the way the assignment is formatted.
It is a relatively light lift, but you could spend a lot more time and get more out of it than I did if you were more disciplined about doing all of the reading.
Take it! Even if you're not interested in working in the tropics but want to take a great FES class, this is one of them!
read thoroughly before class to make the most of the lectures and assignments
It is fun, but if you already have a lot of ecological nowledge and you don't want a review, this may not be the class for you.
Enjoy it and ask a lot of questions because Liza and the other students know a lot.
Expect the workload at the end to increase substantially, but I would still recommend taking this class.
If you are interested in tropical ecology (not just tropical forest ecology), this is a great course to take.

This course is a great jumping-off point for students interested in tropical studies here at F&ES. It is especially useful for students with less of a background in ecology or less knowledge of tropical issues.
Great course but I would gauge what their level of knowledge is going into it to make sure they know what to expect.
A great introduction to tropical ecology.
